original_data.question: A 63-year-old patient presents to the emergency department because of severe left leg pain and tingling. His condition started suddenly 30 minutes ago. He has had hypertension for the past 10 years for which he takes bisoprolol. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.7°F), the blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, and the pulse is 100/min and irregular. On physical examination, the patient appears in severe pain and his left leg is pale and cool. The popliteal pulse is weaker on the left side compared to the right side. Which of the following is the most common cause of this patient's condition?

model_response:
The patient's sudden onset of severe leg pain and tingling, together with the pale and cool leg, are highly suggestive of acute peripheral arterial occlusion. The most common cause of acute peripheral arterial occlusion is arterial emboli. The most common source of arterial emboli is the heart. The patient's irregular heart beat suggests the presence of atrial fibrillation, a common cause of arterial emboli formation. The bisoprolol may have contributed to the patient's bradycardia, which would increase the likelihood of thrombus formation. Hyperhomocysteinemia is a risk factor for venous thrombosis, not arterial thrombosis. Vasculitis is a general term that encompasses many diseases, some of which may cause peripheral arterial occlusion. However, vasculitis is a diagnosis of exclusion and this patient's history and physical examination do not suggest vasculitis. Arterial trauma is a rare cause of acute peripheral arterial occlusion.

Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Hospital department responsible for the administration and provision of immediate medical or surgical care to the emergency patient.
Intensely bad or unpleasant in degree, quality or extent.
Subjective cutaneous sensations (e.g., cold, warmth, tingling, pressure, etc.) that are experienced spontaneously in the absence of stimulation.
A state of being, such as a state of health.
A unit measure of time equal to 60 seconds.

Persistently high systemic arterial BLOOD PRESSURE. Based on multiple readings (BLOOD PRESSURE DETERMINATION), hypertension is currently defined as when SYSTOLIC PRESSURE is consistently greater than 140 mm Hg or when DIASTOLIC PRESSURE is consistently 90 mm Hg or more.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
A cardioselective beta-1 adrenergic blocker. It is effective in the management of HYPERTENSION and ANGINA PECTORIS.
Visible gaseous suspension of carbon and other particulate matter emitted from burning substances.
A single serving of a beverage; any liquid suitable for drinking.

A clear, colorless liquid rapidly absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and distributed throughout the body. It has bactericidal activity and is used often as a topical disinfectant. It is widely used as a solvent and preservative in pharmaceutical preparations as well as serving as the primary ingredient in ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.
Lacking perfect symmetry or evenness.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Intensely bad or unpleasant in degree, quality or extent.
An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
The portion of the lower extremity between the knee and the ankle on the left side of the body.
A clinical manifestation consisting of an unnatural paleness of the skin.
To lower the temperature of something.
Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the west when facing north.
Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the east when facing north.
Used with diseases for causative agents including microorganisms and includes environmental and social factors and personal habits as contributing factors. It includes pathogenesis.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
A state of being, such as a state of health.
